title: Can Atheists Appreciate Chesterton?
summary:
Key ideas:
- Classical philosophy holds that evil is merely the absence of good, but the opposite reduction is more tempting
- Lewis and Chesterton became great moralists by taking the better parts of the modern world, dressing them up in Christian clothing
- Lewis, Augustine, and Tertullian had Christianity in common, but Lewis stood apart as a product of modernity

Key learnings:
- Lewis and Chesterton inherited qualities from modernity that would have been repugnant to many of their Christian predecessors
- Lewis and Chesterton became great writers by using a Christian aesthetic to describe modern virtues
- Atheists can find Good terrifying, but portrayals of Good in fiction can resonate

Key questions:
- Can an atheist appreciate Chesterton?
- What is the necessary ingredient of Christian clothing?
- What is it about the Christian religion that set Lewis and Chesterton apart from their predecessors?
